fields.description:
Survey of screens
Wizards:
 - Launch Instance : single screen, needs help split (done)
 - Launchconfig : single screen, needs help split (done)
 - Scaling Group : single screen, needs help split (done)
 - ELB : single screen, help is split
 - Stack : single screen: needs help split (done)

Detail Pages:
 - Instance : separate screens, monitoring tab needs help
 - Scaling Group : separate screens, help is split
 - ELB : separate screens, help is split
 - Stack : single screen: needs help split
 - User : single screen, help is split
 - Volume : separate screens, help is split
fields.summary: for tabbed pages, need to have one page of help per tab

comments.body: [~tvo], I'm going to split help pages I need to. You'll probably want to adjust yours as well so if there are changes, we're not getting confused.
[~dkavanagh], yes, I need to do mine first - and give you the appropriate filenames.

Hah, I'm coming up with names that just have the tab name appended! :-)

	deleted:    console_create_instances.html
	new file:   console_create_instances_advanced.html
	new file:   console_create_instances_details.html
	new file:   console_create_instances_image.html
	new file:   console_create_instances_security.html
[~dkavanagh]: those are them (for those that exist). Perfect!
[~tvo], did we decide to add help at the bottom of the monitoring tab for instance detail or just go with hover help on individual graphs?
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1694

[~tvo], as [~jloza] noted in the "Description" on this page, the instance details "Monitoring" tab does not have Help.

There is help on the load balancer details "Monitoring" tab.

Is there some help you could create for the instance details "Monitoring" tab?

[~lnajjar], [~dkavanagh]: There was/is no collapsible Help menu anywhere on the screen so that might explain why there is no associated Help topic for it. 
I'll open a doc bug and create the real topic. In the meantime, could we just put a placeholder topic in there with the filename _console_instance_detail_monitoring_ ? Once I get the content checked in, I'll open a PR to get it merged into the code. DO you want it merged into master or 4.2.1?

Verified on Macintosh running Chrome Version 46.0.2490.80 (64-bit), Firefox 41.0.2, and Safari 9.0.1.

Nice, user-friendly work, [~dkavanagh].

UX review passed. Ready for code review.

On second look, I noticed some inconsistencies. On some tabbed pages, opened Help stays open between tabs. On other tabbed pages, opened Help does not stay open between tabs.

It is better for the user to stay in control of the user interface. So, on the following tabbed pages could you please NOT keep Help open between tabs?

Launch instance wizard
Launch configuration wizard
Create scaling group wizard
Create load balancer wizard
Create new stack wizard
Stack details
User details

I made notes in the description and the pages that are "single page" do keep the help open, but where we have separate pages, the browser actually re-loads the page so state from the other page isn't saved. We'd have to do something special to close the help as they change tabs. I'll look into that.
I think your concerns should be addressed now.

The fix does not appear to work consistently across pages.

For example, on "Create load balancer" expanded Help on the first tab causes the Help to display as expanded on the other tabs. On wizards such as "Create new stack," when Help is the "General" tab is closed, the user opens Help in the "Parameters" tab, then goes back to the "General" tab the "General" tab Help is expanded. On stack details, when the user opens Help in the "Template" tab, goes back to the "General" tab, then goes back to the "Template" tab, the opened Help is now closed. Same for user details.

These are just a few examples.

I've fixed the ELB wizard. That was coded a little differently than the rest and so the same fix didn't work there.
The Stack wizard case you found is a peculiar one where the 2nd step isn't valid and we don't reach the code that closes help. I can't just close help in this case because there are times when this code leaves the user on the same tab. Can we say this is not a big enough problem to worry about because it's more complicated to fix?
In the last case, yes. There is only 1 state variable that indicates open or closed help for the entire page. If it's closed, it's closed for all tabs.
Wait, wait. I just pointed out a few examples. These fixes need to be made in all the cases in "Description" above.

And could you please explain in more detail your comment that "The Stack wizard case you found is a peculiar one where the 2nd step isn't valid and we don't reach the code that closes help. I can't just close help in this case because there are times when this code leaves the user on the same tab."

Like, what does "the 2nd step isn't valid" mean? Which step? Why not valid?

And what does "we don't reach the code that closes help" mean?

Yes, I went through the list you provided yesterday to make the changes. Not all cases I noted in the description required the change as I explained. Tabbed pages that are really separate pages won't suffer from this problem.

The 2nd step, meaning the 2nd tab which is "parameters" in that wizard.
If it isn't valid, that means not all the required parameters have been specified.

The comment about the code just gets into the implementation. There is some generic code that handles moving to the next tab, but checking validation first before allowing the user to progress.

[~dkavanagh], my feeble designer mind cannot grok your brilliant developer mind insights.

Can you please explain what you plan to do about each of these usability challenges?

1. Launch new instance: When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

2. Create new launch configuration: When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

3. Create new scaling group: When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

4. Create new load balancer:  When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

5. Create new stack: When the user expands Help on the "Parameters" tab, then goes to the "General" tab, the collapsed "General" tab Help is now expanded. When the user expands Help on the "General" tab, goes to the "Parameters" tab, then returns to the "General" tab, the expanded "General" tab Help is now closed.

6. Instance details: When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

7. Scaling group details: When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

8. Load balancer details: When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

7. Stack details: When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

8. User details: When the user expands Help on one tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab, the expanded Help is now closed.

9. Account details: When the user expands Help on the "General" tab, then goes to the "Quotas" tab, the "Quotas" tab Help is expanded. When the user expands Help on the "Quotas" tab, then goes to the "General" tab, the "General" tab Help is expanded. When the user closes expanded Help on one tab, then goes to the other tab (which had expanded Help), the expanded Help on the other tab is closed.

There are 2 types of tabbed pages.
Single page and multiple pages. The reason is based on how we chose to implement each set of tabs.
In the case where we have multiple pages, 1 per tab (Instances, Scaling Groups, ELB, and Volumes detail pages), we have no memory of what state the help was in last time. If it is really important, we can save that in the session, or a cookie.
In the other screens, I made an attempt to match that behavior, with some obvious weirdness on the stack wizard. I missed the account detail page altogether, but that can be fixed.

Now, I can make the single-page tabbed screens remember their help state if that makes sense. I wonder if a user opens help and find what they need, do they need it open after they've navigated away and back again? Just thinking through the workflow, my intuition is that it doesn't matter to keep it open.

The design principle is "The user is in control." 

So, when a user opens Help on a tab, goes to another tab, then returns to the original tab and the opened Help is now closed, the user is not in control. The user did not close that Help.

The same goes for when the user opens Help on one tab, goes to another tab, and the Help on that tab is opened. The user is not in control. The user did not open Help on the second tab.

It sounds like you have some great ideas to put the user back in control.

I got the account screen working like the others, however in looking at what it would take to do what you're asking, I really question if it's worth the effort. I won't go in to the details but it is a significant effort to make this work the way you're asking for all of those screens, plus I hesitate to add anything more to the session which is already too big (and stored as a cookie, so size is a real concern).

OK. I get the cost-benefit tradeoff.

I'll verify again then assign to [~kgill] so you can do more important work.

Verified again on Macintosh running Chrome Version 46.0.2490.86 (64-bit), Firefox 41.0.2, and Safari 9.0.1.

UX review passed. Ready for code review.
PR 1694 merged

Verified. For each tabbed page, I could find a help page that is tailored to the tab. One exception is volume-monitoring tab where the help content is missing (perhaps OK if no help content is necessary).
